lines.text: Beth, go to your room.
No Uncle William, I will not! I full understand my obligation to you, and I appreciate everything you've done for me... but Alfred and I are not in love with each other! I love Rudy.
What you don't seem to understand, young lady, is that the amalgamation of two fortunes will make you a very rich woman!
Rudy's leaving! If I don't go after him, I'll lose him!
I am telling you what I told your mother... you go out that door, never come back.
[pause]
Oh William...!

[Interrupts]
Constance, be quiet!

[pause. Steps forward]
Uncle William, I'm sorry. You're a dear sweet man, and I owe you a great deal... but I must give you the same answer my mother gave you!
[Turns around and exits]
I do not think your father would be happy with your marriage plans.

[pause]
If we meet after tonight...
If?
It has to be understanding. We will discuss neither your marriage nor mine, but meet rather to deepen our friendship.
[pause]
Agreed?
Agreed.
Your aunt wants me to help you get ready. Mr. Browning will be here any minute.
Thank you Mary.

[Fixes Beth up. Mutters angrily]
The whole thing's a cry shame. That's what it is.
Mary please don't start that again!

[Upset]
Well why shouldn't I? Wouldn't you try to stop me from being pig-headed and throwing my life away?
I'n not throwing my life away! I'm just doing what's expected of me. I love Alfred, you know that.
Are you trying to tell me that you would...

[Interrupts]
NO!
[Crying]
I'm trying to tell me!

[Off stage]
Beth! Are you ready?
Don't go!
I must.
What time is it?

[Pulls out a pocket watch]
It is eleven precisely.
How beautiful. May I?
Of course.
[Hands watch to Beth]
Aren't you afraid you'll lose it, carrying it in your pocket like that without a chain?
I nearly did once. A hooligan tried to take it from me!
[They laugh softly]
It is my most prized possession. It belong to my father and his father before him... and well, I value it as you do you hair.
Never before have I see hair of such luxurious length. Tell me, has it never been cut?
No.
Then whoever issued that command was very wise!

It was my father, and he did not issue commands. I had Scarlett Fever when I was three, and I had to have my hair cut off. When it grew back, my father asked me never to cut it again... and I never will.
You speak of you father in a past tense. Nicht wahr?
Both my parents died when I was a child.
Yesterday?

[laughs]
Forgive me?
Ok. Now please get out.
Begging your pardon ma'am, but how many are we serving today?
Twenty-four.
Oooh, then I better get a bigger bowl!
Oh for heavens sake Mary. It's all make believe.

[Mary exits]
Oh Mary's quite right dear. It is imperitive that you choose the right dish for each occasion.
I learned all that from my mother.

Yes of course you did. After all, your mother was a Schulyer. It's just that, well in her reduced circumstances shall we say, she did have the occasion to entertain on the grand scale which you'll be expected to maintain as the bride of Alfred Browning.
Well, now that we're all here, Alfred has something to say to you Beth

[Nervous]
I...
Well?
I... that is... it would do me great honor...
Go on Alfred, you're doing beautifully!
Thank you Mrs. Constance. What I mean to say Beth is that... your Uncle William and my sister Agnes... have decided that it would be advantageous for us... to marry.

[pause]
Well Beth, what do you say?
I didn't hear a question.
Well she's quite right William. You could say that Alfred has issued a statement. Perhap a plan for a merger.
I have no difficulty seeing the meaning of Alfred's remarks.
Nor do I.

[pause]
Alfred dear. Go back and start again just the way you did before.
It would give me great honor...
[sighs in frustration]
Oh for heavens sake, he's asking you to marry him!
Yes, that's it. I'm asking you... to marry me.
What are you doing here? It's your day off.
I know, but I just had to tell you. The lake in Central Park has frozen over!
If only I can go with you.
Have a headache!
A headache? I can't. Alfred and Ms. Browning are going to pop the question today.

[Sarcastic]
How romantic.
Aren't you going to introduce us to your friend?
Look whose forgotten me manners! My mother would be that ashamed!
[to Beth]
Meet Franz Hollner, and Rudy...
Miller.
Miller. This is my friend, Beth Atherton.

[to Beth]
Are you also an upstairs maid?
Oh no, I'm...

[Interrupts]
Oh no, Beth's a parlor maid!
[Beth glares at her]
Well, with your beauty, you shall be Mistress of the House.
[Takes Beth's hand. Kisses it]

[after revealing Beth's now short hair]
Your hair! What have you done?

Please don't look at me like that! I had to! It was Christmas Eve, and my heart was just bursting with love that... there was this place where you can sell hair to make wigs, and I had no money and... here open this.
[Hands him his present. Rudy opens the present and reveals a small watch chain]
It's for your watch. You know how you cherish it, and I'm always afraid you'll lose it!

[Slowly hands Beth her present]
.
[Whispers]
Open it.
[Beth open her present and takes out two small combs]
I too wished to show you my love. I had no money and... I sold my watch.
[They laugh]
I sold my watch to buy you combs for... for the hair you sold...
[They laugh harder]
... to buy a chain for my watch!
[They stop laughing]
Oh but you are beautiful. You are more beautiful than before.
[They kiss]
I love you so much.
Finish your primping Mary. It is time to set the table.
[Mary sticks her tongue out at him behind his back. Griggs exits]
Oh Mary!
[They both laugh]

[to Mary]
I thought you said he wasn't coming!

[to Franz]
I thought you said she wasn't coming!
You're practicing to be old before your time. I don't know what you aunt and uncle are thinking of; arranging a match like that!

[Defensively]
They're thinking of my future. They don't want me running of with a penny-less music teacher like my mother did.
Did that end up so bad?

[Softens]
Bad? My parent's house was the most wonderful place in the world.
Well then...
That was different then. They were so much in love with each other that nothing else mattered. A love like that just doesn't come along everyday.
Well maybe you...

[Interrupts]
No! I don't want to talk about it. My Uncle William's heart was broken when my mother ran off with my father

[Sympathetic]
Oooh.
That's what Aunt Constance said... an even though he never got over it, he was kind enough to take me in after my parents died... and now I can make up to him for all the pain.
I bet your Aunt Constance told you that too.
You see? She is conceited, rude, impossible churlish girl!
But adorable.
I see nothing adorable with bad manners.
This one has bad manners? The one last week has too many freckles? Sally's friend, that I introduced to you talks to much? You're impossible to please! Seems to me that you don't want to be please.
Perhaps you forget I'm betrothed to Hilda. I cannot.

What's that got to do with it? I have an arranged bride waiting for me at home too, but that doesn't mean I can't look at a pretty girl, does it? Look I'm in the United States. I work hard, send my money home. And when I have free time, I flirt a little. What harm can there be in that?

[pause]
Franz, if you fall in love with one of these oh-so-pretty American girls, you will find out.

[laughs]
Fall in love? I'm not planning to fall in love.
I did not know one fell in love only if one planned to.
I do wish you wouldn't play that dear. It will only bring you pain.
But it doesn't Aunt Constance. It gives me comfort.
Well, then I'm sure it will please your father if he only knew.
Somehow I think he does.

[to Mary]
And when Rudy told me, I said he must be mistaken.
There is no mistake. The young lady was playing a cruel trick common to people in her station!

[to Mary]
And you allowed it, which forces me to change my estimation of you.
I too would have though better of you.

[Angry]
Stop, both of you! What you're saying to me, well maybe I deserve it. But all that stuff about Beth, that's just rubbish!
[Mocking]

"A cruel trick common to people in her station." What station? This isn't Europe and all! She's not a princess, she's just a poor old orphan being forced to marry a man she doesn't love. So she hung out with me for a bit of fun.
And represented herself as someone she was not!
That was my idea, not hers!
She did nothing to mistaken my belief she was a maid in this house!
And why should she? And why should I be standing here, defending the two of you like I'm in a docket
[sp?]
? I would prefer that you both leave!
[Pushes them away]
With pleasure.
[They turn around, then look at Mary. They exit]
Foreigners!
He's gone. He's really gone.
[Crying]
I'll never see him again.
[Beth and Mary cry together. Long pause]
Oh Mary, how selfish of me, not thinking about how you must feel with Franz leaving too.
There are plenty of other fish in the sea.
[pause]
We have to get you home.
What? Oh no, no I can't go home. I can never go home.
Never's a long time as my mother would say... but perhaps you're right for now.
may you have the pleasure of the precious gift of love. #
It is hard for me to keep my anger in while you're looking so beautiful.

[Mad]
Your anger? You were deliberately making fools of Alfred and me!
Don't you think I deserve a bit of revenge?
No!
[pause]
What have I done to you?
You've allowed me to fall in love with you, even though you're engaged to another man.

[Guilty]
I didn't mean to do all that.
None the less, you did.

[Sees Beth with her head down]
Oh don't cry, oh please don't cry!

[Angry]
I'm not crying! Oh I just want to die. I've never been so embarrased in my whole life!
Seems to me you're more angry than anything.

[Begins combing her hair roughly]
That man... that awful man!
He's pretty pushy. I'll give him that.
[Begins to fix Beth's hair]
If he ever tries to come in the same room with me, I'll... I'll...
And he deserves every bit of it too.
[They laugh]
But wouldn't you be angry with him?
That I would, but I would be mixed with pleasure. That man certainly finds you attractive.
Don't be silly, he hates me.
Awww.
...and I hate him.
[pause]
What time is it?
It must be well past ten.
Oh I've got to go home!
Her ladyship and himself won't be home for a while yet!
I want to go!
[Mary exits, defeated]

[after finding out about the Butler's Ball]
. Oh Beth, I am surprised.
[Mary enters]
Mary...
[Mary turns to leave]
No wait, don't go. Come here for a minute. I would like to speak to you.
[pause]
I understand it was because of you my niece didn't stay at that, uh, that...
Ball ma'am.
Yes, the ball. I appreciate your common sense.
Oh, thank you ma'am.
Never the less, I must forbid any furthur association between the two of you.

[Saddened]
Oh my mother would be that upset ma'am. She loves Miss Beth like one of her own.
That does seem harsh doesn't it? Well, it's Mr. Schulyer's wish.
Yes ma'am. Will that be all ma'am?
Yes dear, you may go now. Good night.
Good night ma'am. Good night Miss Beth.

[Whispers]
Good Night
[Mary exits]
Excuse me, may I cut in?
Oh we don't do that here.
Please, this is my sister and I have a very important message from her mother.
Is this true?
Yes.
[Takes Beth away from dancer and dances with her]
Aren't you going to thank me?
Thank you.
I wasn't planning on being here tonight...
I *prefer* to dance in silence.

[to Beth]
This our dance.
Is it?
Well, I...
I... thought... not.
[Continues dancing]
UGH, you are the rudest!
Smile! The judges are watching.
I don't care who's watching!
